title: Tattershall Lakes Walking Route

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Tattershall village sign
images.caption: Tattershall village sign. In the Market Place, with the Fortescue Arms behind. The sign portrays Holy Trinity church and the castle.

images.title: Kate Jewell / Tattershall, Lincolnshire
images.caption: Tattershall, Lincolnshire. Probably the most photographed view from the roof top walk of the Castle tower. Here you can see, left to right, the village, the castle guardhouse which is now the National Trust gift shop and information centre, the Collegiate Church of the Holy Trinity and the village of Coningsby (in TF2257) beyond. The tree lined river in the middle distance is the River Bain.

images.title: Richard Croft / Tattershall lakes
images.caption: Tattershall Lakes Country Park seen from the keep of Tattershall Castle

images.title: Ian Paterson / The Fairways Inn
images.caption: The Fairways Inn Bar and Restaurant associated with Tattershall Lakes.

images.title: Richard Croft / Bovine reflections
images.caption: Grazing cattle reflected in a calm River Witham near Tattershall Bridge

images.title: Richard Croft / Dogdyke
images.caption: The Packet Inn and River Witham at Dogdyke

images.title: Dave Hitchborne / The Hornblower, Dogdyke
images.caption: The Hornblower, Dogdyke. A small river craft turns out of the River Witham and heads for the pub at the entrance to the Horncastle Canal.

description: This waterside walk takes you along Tattershall Lakes and the River Bain in the Lincolnshire village of Tattershall. The walk starts in the village centre on the River Bain, next to the remains of Tattershall Castle . The 15th century castle and grounds are run by the National Trust and well worth a visit. There's a splendid view over the village and surrounding countryside from the roof top walk of the Castle tower. From the village centre it is a short walk south to the lakes. A public footpath runs along the eastern side of the lakes and the River Bain. It runs south to Dogdyke where there are views of the River Witham and a nice pub where you can enjoy refreshments before returning on the same footpaths.
